1.title: How Much Power Does Magneto Need to Rip Iron from Blood?
1.plot: Magneto proves he's one of the most powerful mutants in X2 X-Men United when he pulls iron out of a guard, but how powerful of a magnetic field would he need to do that? Kyle has the bloody details on this week's Because Science.

2.title: The Physics Behind The Last Jedi's Coolest Scene!
2.plot: Star Wars has changed pop culture and The Last Jedi may have done it again with an epic space tactic, but how would it work? Kyle has the lightspeed physics on this week's Because Science.

3.title: Would Wolverine Be the Ultimate Body Builder?
3.plot: Wolverine is known for his healing factor, but should also make him known as the ultimate muscle man too? Kyle does some mental exercising on this week's Because Science.

4.title: How Black Bolt Shatters Mountains with Sound!
4.plot: Of the many amazing powers in comics, sound powers like those of Black Bolt are the most understandable, but how does he shatter mountains? Kyle has the sound breaking science on this week's Because Science.

5.title: Are Alien Xenomorphs Really No Match for Darth Vader?
5.plot: It's the ultimate sci-fi nerd debate: would the acid blood of Alien xenomorphs stand a chance against the weapon of Jedi and Sith? Kyle answers the burning question on this week's Because Science.

6.title: How To Go Super Saiyan with Science!
6.plot: One of the most iconic anime transformation is going Super Saiyan, but is there a way to explain Goku's ultimate form? Kyle has the hyperbolic time on this week's Because Science.

7.title: How Black Panther's Vibranium Suit Works!
7.plot: Black Panther comes out this week and gives us another look at vibranium but this time in a suit. But how does it work? Kyle has the Wakandan science on this week's Because Science.

8.title: What Toxin Is on Poison Ivy's Lips?
8.plot: One of Batman's most iconic villains is Poison Ivy, who is not just known for her power over plant life, but also her poisonous lips. But what poison do her lips actually have? Kyle has the poisonous anecdote on this week's Because Science.

9.title: What Would Really Happen if a Vibranium Meteor Hit Earth?
9.plot: Black Panther showed us how a vibranium meteor impacted Wakanda in many ways, but would it play out the same way in real life? Kyle has the Earth shaking science on this week's Because Science.

10.title: Why You Don't Actually Want Super Strength
10.plot: Among the most famous super powers, super strength is always a strong choice, but would it actually be more of a curse than a gift? Kyle makes a powerful argument on this week's Because Science.

11.title: Why Do Pacific Rim Jaegers Need Two Brains?
11.plot: Pacific Rim jaegers are mighty machines, so mighty that they need 2 brains to operate, but why is that? Kyle has the mind blowing details on this week's Because Science.

12.title: Could Superman Really Make Diamonds with His Bare Hands?
12.plot: Superman is known for his super powers, but could he be capable of even more? Kyle has the crushing evidence on this week's Because Science.

13.title: How Science Explains The Last Jedi's "Plot Holes"
13.plot: Star Wars The Last Jedi left many fans critical of the plot, but not EVERYTHING was wrong. Kyle has the truth from a certain point of view on this week's Because Science.

14.title: Can You Run Through Harry Potter's Platform 9 3/4?
14.plot: Everyone knows that the journey to Hogwarts in Harry Potter begins with running through a magical wall to Platform 9 3.

15.title: The Truth about Space War
15.plot: We've all seen fighting in space, but is any of it actually right? Kyle battles it out on this week's Because Science.

16.title: Why You Don't Want Super Speed
16.plot: Super speed is one of the coolest super powers in comics because of heroes like the Flash, but would it really be that great in real life? Kyle has the fast facts on this week's Because Science.

17.title: How Thanos Throws a Moon
17.plot: Avengers Infinity War will give us one of the most powerful villains in Thanos, but what would it take for him to throw a moon? Kyle has the Earth shattering science on this week's Because Science.

18.title: How Proton Torpedoes Destroyed the Death Star
18.plot: Star Wars' battle above Yavin 4 gave us the iconic defeat of the first Death Star, but how did the rebellion actually do it? Kyle stays on target on this week's Because Science.

19.title: How to Forge Thor's New Weapon
19.plot: Thor may have lost Mjolnir in Thor Ragnarok, but what would it take to actually make his new one? Kyle hammers out the details on this week's Because Science.

20.title: Can You Slice Bullets Like Deadpool?
20.plot: When we first met the merc with a mouth, he was splitting bullets in mid-air like a pro, but Deadpool 2 shows it's harder than it looks, so which one is right? Kyle has the cut down on this week's Because Science.

21.title: Is Han Solo Wrong about Hyperspace?
21.plot: Han Solo gave one of the earliest lessons about hyperspace in Star Wars, but was he right? Kyle goes to light speed on this week's Because Science.

22.title: Never Do a Superhero Landing
22.plot: We've seen a lot of heroes from Batman to Iron Man do superhero landings, but are they actually a good idea? Kyle does some number and bone crunching on this week's Because Science.

23.title: What if Majora's Mask Stopped OUR Moon?
23.plot: Link faced a terrible fate in The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask, but did he really have 3 days to prevent it if it were OUR moon? Kyle has the earthly science on this week's Because Science.

24.title: Can You Snap in the Infinity Gauntlet?
24.plot: Thanos wields the ultimate power with the Infinity Gauntlet and could take out half the universe with a snap. But can you actually snap with it on? Kyle has the real life test on this week's Because Science.

25.title: How to Fight a T-Rex (and Win)
25.plot: Jurassic Park and Jurassic World showed us that the Tyrannosaurus Rex is the king of dinosaurs, but could you fight it and win? Kyle has the dino details on this week's Because Science.

1.title: Why THE FLASH Is Faster Than You Think!
1.plot: We all know The Flash is a speedster who can run super fast. But because he can move so fast, he must also have the ability to see, process and react to things super fast, too--probably getting input in real time--no lag like the rest of us.

2.title: How Does THE WALKING DEAD Zombie Virus Work?
2.plot: Everyone in The Walking Dead is already infected with the zombie virus. So it's not the virus from the zombie bites that kill their victims, it must be something else. Kyle Hill is on the case, and drops some real-life zombie knowledge along the way.

3.title: Nature's Real Life MONSTERS!
3.plot: The monsters that appear in pop culture are scary, sure--but nature makes a lot of its own extremely creepy creatures, as Kyle Hill is happy to explain. Meet nature's own vampires, body snatchers and more.

4.title: The Science of GHOSTS!
4.plot: Could there be logical, scientific reasons for things that go bump in the night--or at least people's reactions and beliefs based on them? Kyle Hill thinks so. His "brains before boos" examples include confirmation bias, sleep paralysis and more.

5.title: Top 3 SCARIEST THINGS in Real Life!
5.plot: Sure, there's lots of terrifying stuff in fiction--monsters, aliens, ghosts--but what about real life? Don't Google it, Kyle Hill is here to scare you with really scary things that really exist: animal bombs, liquid oxygen and Chernobyl.

6.title: Could INTERSTELLAR's Wormhole be a Time Machine?
6.plot: Kyle Hill talks about the scientific theories underpinning the action in the movie Interstellar, including wormholes, white and black holes, the folding of space time and using a combo of all of those for backward time travel.

7.title: Science of HALO's Ringworlds
7.plot: The ringlike structures that exist in pop culture from games like Halo to books like Larry Niven's Ringworld and movies like Elysium aren't quite buildable with current tech, but Kyle Hill explains what it would take to build them, theoretically.

8.title: The Real Science in the HUNGER GAMES
8.plot: The Muttations in The Hunger Games are mostly horrible genetically modified organisms that attack Katniss, but there are real GMOs that just might help solve the world's problems--including hunger. Also...the lyrebird is a lot like a Jabberjay.

9.title: The IMITATION GAME's Enigma Machine Science!
9.plot: Alan Turing, as portrayed by Benedict Cumberbatch in the movie The Imitation Game, was a brilliant man who used science and math to deduce the Enigma machine's flaw, and saved millions of lives in the process. Kyle Hill explains how.

10.title: Why Can't Anyone Lift THOR's Hammer? - Ask Kyle
10.plot: Kyle Hill is Nerdist's Science Editor, but he's also a helpful guy--so he's answering questions sent in by viewers on the topics of quantum entanglement, mirages, the Big Bang theory and Thor's hammer.

11.title: How Do Dragons Breathe Fire?
11.plot: Kyle Hill realizes there are not actually dragons, especially not charismatic dragons with Benedict Cumberbatch's voice, like Smaug. That aside, he explains how dragons' fire-breathing could work, if they were real.

12.title: How FAST Is Santa Claus?
12.plot: Kyle Hill, with help from a Spy magazine article, made a list (and presumably checked it twice) of all the different variables of Santa's gift-delivery trip, and comes to a startling conclusion on how fast Santa would have to go to make it happen.

13.title: New Years Resolution Psychology!
13.plot: Apparently 50 to 60% of us still make New Year's resolutions, but most people can't keep them for more than a week. So what are the secrets to sticking to your resolutions? Kyle Hill looked into it, so you can cross that off your list.

1.title: Top 5 Science Stories of 2014!
1.plot: Kyle Hill is the Science Editor for Nerdist, so of course he has a list of his top five science stories of 2014. Giant dinosaurs, a paralyzed man regaining the ability to walk, landing on a comet and two more made the cut.

2.title: Can We Have Star Wars' Lightsabers in Real Life?
2.plot: Kyle Hill has a new hope for all of you young padawans just itchin' to get yourselves one of those sweet, sweet lightsabers. Well, sorta. Most of the "science of lightsabers is complete fiction, but he does find one thing about them plausible.

3.title: Do STAR TREK's Transporters Turn You Into a Different Person?
3.plot: In a highly philosophical episode of Because Science, Kyle Hill tackles the question of whether or not you are the same person once you are disassembled, beamed as a matter stream, and then reassembled by Star Trek's transporters.

4.title: How Doctor Who's TARDIS Is Bigger on the Inside
4.plot: In this edition of Ask Kyle, viewers cover a lot of ground, from whether or not an Assassin's Creed leap of faith is possible, to how artificial gravity on spaceships and space stations might work, to how the Tardis could be bigger on the inside.

5.title: How Does THOR Fly?
5.plot: In this edition of Ask Kyle, viewers cover a lot of ground, from whether or not an Assassin's Creed leap of faith is possible, to how artificial gravity on spaceships and space stations might work, to how the Tardis could be bigger on the inside.

6.title: How Fast Will ZOMBIES Take Over The World?
6.plot: Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill explains how mathematics students from The University of Ottawa and Carleton University modeled a zombie outbreak and figured out what the time-line for zombies outnumbering humans would be.

7.title: Real Life CUPID is TERRIFYING
7.plot: Perhaps you've never considered what Cupid's wingspan would need to be to keep his diapered butt in the sky--but Kyle Hill has. The calculations for what a real-life Cupid would look like are pretty scary stuff.

8.title: How MARY POPPINS Flies & More - Ask Kyle
8.plot: Viewers wonder whether you could swim in a coin vault like Scrooge McDuck, what the science behind vampirism or lycanthropy might be, and how big Mary Poppins' umbrella would need to be for her to fly with it. Kyle Hill gives answers.

9.title: ZELDA Timeline According to Quantum Mechanics
9.plot: Using the Hyrule Historia's official time-line for all of The Legend of Zelda games as a jumping-off point, Kyle Hill explains how there can be more than one Zelda universe with the theory of infinite parallel universes.

10.title: Understanding Consciousness in CHAPPIE
10.plot: Leading scientific thought-provoker Kyle Hill uses the movie character Chappie to help illustrate questions about consciousness, including the hard and easy problems of consciousness as raised by philosopher David Chalmers.

11.title: Can ADVENTURE TIME'S Land of Ooo Happen in Real Life?
11.plot: A nuclear war-type event, the Great Mushroom War, blew a hole in the planet and killed most of the humans of Ooo. We have nuclear weapons _ could we blow ourselves into an Adventure Time situation? Kyle Hill works it out.

12.title: How Much Would a DEATH STAR Cost?
12.plot: The Death Star is huge--160 km across--and can be mistaken for a moon. So it seems that it would take a lot of money and power to create and run something like that. Wonder how much? Kyle Hill has some answers.

13.title: Does SCOOBY-DOO Have a Speech Disorder?
13.plot: Channeling his inner Scooby gang, Kyle Hill tackles the mystery of what exactly is wrong with Scooby-Doo's speech with the help of Dr. Steven Long. He creates a custom diagnosis for the cartoon dog and also coins the term "Scooby Snaccent.

14.title: Why is the HULK Green?
14.plot: Bruce Banner was hit with gamma radiation that gave him the ability to turn into The Hulk when angered. But what about his super-heroic condition would make him take on a green hue? Kyle Hill has a marvelous answer.

15.title: Why Doesn't IRON MAN's Suit Kill Him?
15.plot: Iron Man makes some pretty incredible maneuvers in his suit, and inertia should bang Tony Stark around pretty hard, but it doesn't. Kyle Hill hypothesizes as to how Tony might survive using the Iron Man suit and its extreme moves.

16.title: How Does DAREDEVIL See Without Sight?
16.plot: The man without fear, Daredevil, is blind--but he can perceive the world around him using all of his senses. Every one of us has the Daredevil-esque ability to get information about the world around us without our eyes, as Kyle Hill explains.

17.title: How Does CAPTAIN AMERICA's Super-Soldier Serum Work?
17.plot: Scientists in the Marvel Universe are a bit ahead of us in the real world, but there are real-world techniques that actual scientists might someday use to suppress and activate certain genes and deliver medications with the help of light rays.

18.title: How Soon Will We Reach ULTRON-level AI?
18.plot: Avengers: Age of Ultron features a sentient artificial intelligence (AI) called Ultron that wishes to destroy all humans. So, how long do we have to worry about this scary AI? Kyle Hill is on the case with the most current scientific thinking.

19.title: GAME OF THRONES Science: Dragons, Hodor & More
19.plot: There's no such thing as dragons, but if there were, how many people would they need to eat a day to power their flight and fire-breathing? What is wrong with Hodor? Could a big man crush another man's skull? Kyle Hill looks into it, Because Science.

20.title: Will We Ever Have a MAD MAX Gas Shortage?
20.plot: In the Mad Max universe, gas (among other things) is a scarce and precious commodity, something we've been warned could happen in the real world. But it hasn't happened yet. Kyle Hill gives his opinion on whether it's likely to occur.

21.title: How Does QUICKSILVER Listen to Music?
21.plot: Speedsters experience life differently than normal folks. So how can Quicksilver listen to a song in his headphones at normal speed if he's running super fast? Kyle Hill has some thoughts on how science can explain this musical feat.

22.title: What's in SPIDER-MAN'S Web-Shooters?
22.plot: The real science behind the spider silk that Spider-Man swings around on is the subject of this episode of Because Science. Spider silk is fascinating, whether it's coming out of an artificial web shooter or the backside of a spider.

23.title: We Already Have Human Clones: Identical Twins
23.plot: Orphan Black is packed with clones, but no one has cloned a human yet, at least that we know of. However, nature clones humans all the time. Randy and Jason Sklar join Kyle Hill for a twinteresting take on naturally occurring clones: identical twins.

24.title: Can We Bring Back EXTINCT Animals?
24.plot: In the movie Jurassic World, scientists are able to not only bring dinosaurs back from extinction, but also mix up bits of genetic code to create more exciting creatures. That's not quite possible in the real world, as Kyle Hill explains.

25.title: Can Doctor Who's SONIC SCREWDRIVER Actually Be Made?
25.plot: The sonic screwdriver is an amazing piece of tech that does a bunch of things, but Kyle Hill is concentrating on just one of its abilities: manipulating objects with sound, and whether that is doable with today's science.

26.title: Should You Eat BRAINS?
26.plot: TV shows like Hannibal and The Walking Dead feature people parts on the menu for humans (and zombies). Kyle Hill looks into the real-life history of humans eating other humans, and the pros and cons of such a culinary choice. Short answer: no.

27.title: How Does a TERMINATOR'S Skin Survive?
27.plot: Terminators use human tissue, including a covering of skin, to help them fit in with their human prey. Kyle Hill explains how that skin could work, and how the aging of the skin as seen in Terminator: Genisys could happen.

28.title: How Do POKEBALLS Really Work?
28.plot: Not much Pok'© Science is explained to visitors to the Pok'©mon universe, but one mystery stands out: how Pok'© Balls work. Many fan theories exist, and some of them are pretty bleak. Kyle Hill speculates on the best theories.

29.title: How Does ANT MAN's Suit Work?
29.plot: In the movies and comics, Ant-Man's abilities are explained by "Pym particles, which are not a thing in real life. Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill presents a non-Pym particle explanation for how Ant-Man's suit might work.

30.title: How Does BATMAN'S Cape Glide?
30.plot: One of the most enjoyable items in Batman's arsenal is his cape, which looks super cool and can be used as a glider in the game Batman: Arkham Knight. Kyle Hill poses the question, "how big would the cape need to be to really work as a glider?

31.title: How Big Could a TITAN Be in Real Life?
31.plot: The Titans from Attack on Titan are big humanoid giant things who rampage around, eating people. They are very scary. And, according to Kyle Hill, some of them are just way too big to function--Because Science.

32.title: Is HUMAN TORCH-Like Combustion Possible?
32.plot: The Human Torch has some pretty cool powers. Obviously real people don't burst into flames for fun and crime-fighting _ but sometimes real people do burst into flames. Kyle Hill looks at the very uncool spontaneous human combustion.

33.title: How Does DRAGON BALL Z's Time Chamber Work?
33.plot: The Hyperbolic Time Chamber in Dragon Ball Z is a place where Goku and Gohan spend one year training, but outside the chamber only one day passes by. Kyle Hill uses his super science powers to explain how that sort of time dilation could work.

34.title: Why Can't Anyone Recognize SUPERMAN?
34.plot: How is it possible that the people closest to Superman and Clark Kent can't tell they're the same person? Kyle Hill looks at a few possible explanations before settling on a final, surprising conclusion.

35.title: What's the Scientific Difference between Fast and Slow ZOMBIES?
35.plot: There are, essentially, two different types of zombies in pop culture: fast (World War Z) and slow (The Walking Dead). Using the book Do Zombies Dream of Undead Sleep as a primer, Kyle Hill considers the differences between the two types.

36.title: Could the MATRIX Actually Be Powered By Human Batteries?
36.plot: Humans are good for a lot of things, but being batteries doesn't seem to be one of their strong suits. Kyle Hill investigates whether or not the immense simulation known as the Matrix could really be powered by human batteries.

37.title: How Does the GHOSTBUSTERS Proton Pack Work?
37.plot: Both generations of Ghostbusters use particle accelerators to bust ghosts. Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill isn't commenting on whether or not you could use one to catch a ghost, but he can tell you whether or you could strap one to your back.

38.title: What Is in JOKER Venom?
38.plot: Batman's greatest villain, The Joker, sometimes uses a nasty concoction to make his victims die laughing, resulting in hideous grinning corpses. Find out if the comic's explanation of the mixture holds up to real-world science.

39.title: The Science Behind RICK AND MORTY's Rickstaverse!
39.plot: Adult Swim's Rick and Morty have a portal gun that allows them access to the infinite Rickstaverse of alternate time-lines, a concept that aligns with the many worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics, as Kyle Hill explains.

40.title: The Hive Mind in the Real World
40.plot: Hive minds in fiction are usually pretty unpleasant, from Star Trek's Borg to the virus victims in The Hive. Kyle Hill runs down some relatively pleasant examples of swarms, the closest to things to hive minds the real world has to offer.

41.title: When Will We Walk on Mars?
41.plot: The movie The Martian has a lot of people wondering when we'll actually get humans to Mars in real life. NASA has a time-line for that, and Kyle Hill has a rundown, plus at look at what's already happened on Mars.

42.title: Where a Vampire Should Bite
42.plot: Just in case you ever become a vampire, or if you know a few who just aren't getting the most out of their prey, Kyle Hill has some pointers for where to bite to get the biggest meal, where to bite to kill and where to bite to spare the victim.

43.title: Is Sleep Paralysis Giving You Night Terrors?
43.plot: Some people (about 6% of the population) experience sleep paralysis--they can't move or breathe well, and they see something scary in the room with them. Supernatural interpretations used to be the norm for sleep paralysis, but science can explain it.

44.title: How Many Calories Are in the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man?
44.plot: No one would actually want to eat the Stay Puft Marshmallow man (unless they could find similarly large graham crackers and chocolate squares), but it's still a fun thought experiment to try to figure out how many calories he has in him.

45.title: How Do Modern Hoverboards Work?
45.plot: Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill takes an in-depth look into how two different hover board manufacturers make their super cool real-life hover-boards work using two different approaches to making a board hover.

46.title: How Powerful Are FALLOUT 4's Energy Weapons?
46.plot: Most people probably don't consider how powerful their video game weapons would be using real-world calculations, but Kyle Hill isn't most people. He calculates just how powerful the energy weapons in Fallout 4 need to be to vaporize enemies.

47.title: How Many FALLOUT Nuka Colas Could You Drink Before Dying?
47.plot: In the wastelands, the preferred drink has always been Nuka-Cola. It's delicious, but irradiated. Kyle Smith does the math to find out how many of these dangerous drinks you could swig before they'd send you to the big vending machine in the sky.

48.title: Could FALLOUT-Sized Bugs Ever Happen?
48.plot: Radroaches, Stingwings and other enormous bugs are just some of the many wondrous creatures created by the, well, fallout from nuclear war that leads to the events of Fallout 4. But can bugs ever really get that big?

49.title: Why Han Solo is a Time Traveler
49.plot: Star Wars' science fiction and real life science collide as Kyle Hill details his theory that Han Solo must be a pretty old guy even in A New Hope, because of how long the Kessel Run is and how fast even non-hyperspace travel is.

50.title: How We Already Have Real TIE Fighters
50.plot: You may recognize TIE fighters from Star Wars. "TIE stands for twin ion engine, and it turns out that they actually exist in the real world. It's real-life rocket science as explained by Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill.

51.title: Why Kylo Ren's Lightsaber Works
51.plot: Kylo Ren's enormous lightsaber with crossguard blades ignited a red-hot debate that may never end. Kyle Hill speaks about the history of swords and the speculative science behind lightsabers, and declares Kylo Ren's to be totally cool in every way.

52.title: Is Poison Immunity Possible?
52.plot: When Westley challenges Vizzini to a battle of wits in The Princess Bride, he poisons both cups because he's immune to the poison. Kyle Hill looks at whether that's possible, and also what real poison is closest to the fictional iocane powder.

53.title: How Is MEN IN BLACK'S Rocket Car Possible in Real Life?
53.plot: Using the classic "driving on the ceiling of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel scene from the original Men in Black as the example, Kyle Hill presents a primer for how to do nerdy physics analyses with math, math and more math. Why? Because Science.

1.title: Could You Be Sucked Into Space Through a Hole?
1.plot: If the movies are to be believed, a hole in a spaceship or airplane is super bad news, and anything not bolted down will be sucked right out. Kyle Hill knows the movies are not to be believed in this case, and he explains why.

2.title: How Does Mind Control Work in Jessica Jones?
2.plot: On the Netflix show Jessica Jones, the extremely evil Kilgrave uses viruses to control the minds of his victims. Kyle Hill investigates what creatures in nature come the closest to this type of mind control power.

3.title: How TR-8R's Lightsaber-Blocking Baton Works
3.plot: One of the coolest parts of Star Wars: The Force Awakens is the appearance of TR-8R (FN-2199), the Stormtrooper who carries the lightsaber-resistant riot control baton and knows how to use it. But how might the baton work?

4.title: Is the X-Files' Agent Mulder Crazy?
4.plot: The X-Files' Fox Mulder believes in a lot of conspiracy theories, and people in real life do, too. Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill channels his inner Scully to look into the psychology behind wanting to believe.

5.title: Why Does Fallout's Nuka-Cola Quantum Glow Blue?
5.plot: To figure out why Nuka-Cola Quantum glows blue and if that's feasible, Kyle Hill first examines whether nuclear radiation can make things glow, if blue is the color and what's in Nuka-Cola Quantum that might do all these things.

6.title: How Does Deadpool's Healing Factor Work?
6.plot: Deadpool has a healing factor that allows him to survive just about anything, including decapitation. Nature's version of Deadpool, the axolotl, can't quite regrow a head, but it can regenerate limbs and even brain tissue.

7.title: How Iceman Is Actually a Bomb!
7.plot: Iceman can supercool himself and create ice and control it. Like we said, supercool. But. As Kyle Hill makes ice crystal clear, if he really did all that cooling, he'd also generate a lot of heat, and stuff would go boom.

8.title: Which Pokemon Should You REALLY Choose?
8.plot: There are a lot of things to consider when choosing your starter Pok'©mon, and Kyle Hill throws a few extra on the list, including how the strengths and weaknesses add up versus the Gym Leaders and Elite Four in the original game.

9.title: Why Don't Walking Dead Zombies Decompose?
9.plot: The Walking Dead's zombies are dead, and they seem pretty fragile. But they don't decompose the way normal dead bodies do. Kyle Hill has a theory on how that could be, and also reveals some of the postmortem stages a human body goes through.

10.title: How Does Superman's Heat Vision Work?
10.plot: Heat vision is one of Superman's defining superpowers, whether it's portrayed as heat, lasers or pure energy shooting from his eyeballs. Kyle Hill figures out how much heat Superman could produce, assuming absorbed solar energy powers it.

11.title: Why Batman's Grappling Hook Should Kill More People
11.plot: The Dark Knight has a rule for himself: no killing. But, as Kyle Hill explains, if he used his grappling hook to stop people from falling as he does in many movies, he'd inadvertently break that no killing rule for sure.

12.title: 12 Ways Superman Could Beat Batman Instantly (But Won't)
12.plot: Two of the biggest superheroes throw down in Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice. Kyle Hill maintains that any fight between the two would end quickly in Superman's favor, and reveals 12 ways Superman could, uh, kill Batman. Not that he would.

13.title: Can Kylo Ren Lift Thor's Hammer?
13.plot: Building on his earlier answer as to how Thor's Hammer Mjolnir works plus a statement made in Avengers: Age of Ultron, Kyle Hill answers a viewer question about whether or not Kylo Ren could use the Force to move Thor's hammer.

14.title: Why Does Darth Vader Breathe Like That?
14.plot: Kylo Ren's idol and grandpa, Darth Vader, cut a dashing figure in his classy black ensemble--but is that suit doing more than just making him look super cool and menacing? Kyle Hill thinks so, the explanation also covers that classic Vader sound.

15.title: How Acidic is the Xenomorph Blood from ALIEN?
15.plot: The Xenomorph of ALIEN fame is one of the most iconic monsters of all time and its acidic blood is equally iconic, but how acidic would it really be? Kyle does some blood chemistry on this week's Because Science.

16.title: Could a Lightsaber Cut Through Captain America's Shield?
16.plot: Kyle Hill discusses what would happen in a match-up that could someday happen in a comic or something now that Star Wars and Marvel are part of the same happy corporate family: lightsaber vs. Captain America's shield.

17.title: Why Death by Lava Is Much Worse Than in the Movies
17.plot: Lava deaths as shown in movies like The Lord of the Rings: Return of the King and Terminator 2 are not exactly scientifically accurate, but that's probably a good thing, as Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill explains.

18.title: Iron Man's Secret Superpower Will Help Him in CIVIL WAR
18.plot: Iron Man and Captain America are at odds with each other in Captain America: Civil War, so it's likely Iron Man might take a few on the metal jaw from Cap. But as Kyle Hill explains, that will probably not knock him out.

19.title: Could Spider-Man Swing on Actual Spider Silk?
19.plot: Spider-Man is finally webslinging in the MCU thanks to Captain America Civil War, but could he use REAL spider silk? Kyle uses his spider sense in this week's Because Science.

20.title: How Does Ant-Man Make His Civil War Transformation?
20.plot: Captain America: Civil War introduced movie fans to Ant-Man's ability to get very big and become Giant-Man. Kyle Hill uses his ability to relate pop culture to science to figure out how this big power might work.

21.title: Could Wolverine Get a Tattoo?
21.plot: Would Wolverine's healing factor have any impact on him getting and keeping a tattoo? Kyle Hill works it out, first by describing how tattoos actually work, and then how the healing factor would fit in.

22.title: How Does CatDog Poop?
22.plot: There are a lot of fascinating questions out there that could be answered. But, two hundred people on Twitter must be appeased, so Kyle Hill is answering their question of how CatDog poops, and using the mites that live on human faces to do it.

23.title: How Superheroes Phase Through Walls Is All Wrong!
23.plot: Many superheroes, like Vision, Kitty Pryde or The Flash can "phase through walls, and it's all explained away in comics and movies in ways that don't pass Kyle Hill's science radar. Don't worry, he has an idea on how phasing could be explained.

24.title: How Quick is Quicksilver?
24.plot: Quicksliver has another standout moment in X-Men: Apocalypse, as he saves his mutant homies from an explosive situation at the X-Mansion. Kyle Hill does his thing to figure out how fast Quicksilver is going in the scene.

25.title: Can Game of Thrones' Daenerys Targaryen Get Sunburned?
25.plot: Daenerys Targaryen has a lot of titles: Khaleesi of the Great Grass Sea, Queen of Meereen, the Unburnt. Kyle Hill explores the science of fire burns versus sunburns to figure out if Daenerys would be able to add "the Unsunburnt" to her list of names.

26.title: What Really Happens if You Decapitate Deadpool?
26.plot: In the comics, Deadpool has literally lost his head a number of times and lived to tell the tale. Kyle Hill formulates a theory on whether that's plausible, and estimates how much Deadpool could lose of himself and still regenerate back to full size.

27.title: How Much Can Captain America Drink?
27.plot: Thanks to his increased metabolism from the Super Soldier serum, Captain America can't get drunk - or can he? Kyle does the alcoholic math on this week's Because Science.

28.title: Can Thor's Hammer Stop the Juggernaut?
28.plot: Thor's Hammer can only be wielded or moved by those who are worthy and the Juggernaut can't be stopped once he has momentum, so what would happen if they met?? Kyle has the potentially universe shattering answer on this week's Because Science.

29.title: How Does Pokemon Go Work?
29.plot: We all know that Pokemon Go wants you to catch 'em all, but how does it actually work? Kyle has the Pokescience on this week's Because Science.

30.title: Why Star Trek Transporters Are Sci-Fi's Most Impressive Technology!
30.plot: One of Star Trek's signature technologies is the transporter, but if you look deeper into how they would actually work, they are the greatest piece of sci-fi technology. Kyle beams down some science on this week's Because Science.

31.title: How Strong Could One Punch Man Really Be?
31.plot: Everyone already knows that One Punch Man is pretty strong, but could his power be even MORE ridiculous? Kyle has a fistful of science on this week's Because Science.

32.title: Could Stranger Things' "Upside Down" Really Exist?
32.plot: One of the more stranger things of Stranger Things is the Upside Down, but could it actually be a reality? Kyle explores the universe on this week's Because Science.

33.title: Would a Futurama Sized Ice Cube Stop Global Warming?
33.plot: Good news everyone. Global warming is a real thing, ok so not really good news. Futurama had their own solution for it, but would that really work? Kyle heats up some science on this week's Because Science.

34.title: Why Don't Lightsabers Burn Your Hands Off?
34.plot: We've covered many aspects of lightsabers but by popular demand, we are doing another. With how powerful lightsabers are, why don't they burn their holder's hand? Kyle answers the heated debate on this week's Because Science.

35.title: Is the Flash Fast Enough to Launch a Rocket?
35.plot: The Flash is the fastest man alive, but is he fast enough to make a rocket escape the Earth's atmosphere? Kyle has the rocket science on this week's Because Science.

36.title: Would Dragon Ball Z Gravity Training Kill You?
36.plot: In Dragon Ball Z, Goku and Vegeta had to step up their game constantly and train in extreme conditions like intense gravity, but what would that do to a normal human body? Kyle goes over 9000 to find out on this week's Because Science.

37.title: Are Wolverine's Claws Too Big For His Body?
37.plot: In all the X-Men movies and comics, Wolverine's adamantium claws are his signature feature, but could they really fit in his arms? Kyle breaks down some Loganatomy on this week's Because Science.

38.title: How Many Wonka Fizzy Drinks Would It Take To Float?
38.plot: In Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Charlie and Grandpa Joe get lifted into the air thanks to the Wonka's Fizzy Lifting Drink, but could this work in reality? In honor of the late great Gene Wilder, Kyle takes a fizzy lifted look on this week's Because Science.

39.title: Could Mass Effect Weapons Work in Real Life?
39.plot: Mass Effect has a lot of cool weaponry but are they more realistic than you think? Kyle explains on this week's Because Science.

40.title: How Strong is Luke Cage's Skin?
40.plot: What's so special about Luke Cage that he is seemingly indestructible? Kyle Hill breaks down the science and shows us how Luke Cage's skin is stronger than spider silk and diamond, and is even on a level comparable to Kevlar.

41.title: What Would Happen if Galactus Consumed the Earth?
41.plot: Galactus, the only survivor in the universe before the Big Bang, may be the most feared being. His hunger is so great that he has to consume the life energy of planets. Kyle Hill answers the important question: what exactly would happen if Earth was consumed by Galactus?

42.title: The Physics of The Flash's Infinite Mass Punch!
42.plot: Kyle Hill, master of science, runs us through the physics of the Flash's infinite mass punch.

43.title: How to Hunt Werewolves with Science!
43.plot: The legend of werewolves has existed for thousands of years, but how could you find them in real life? Kyle sheds some light on this Halloween fright on this week's Because Science.

44.title: Would the Death Star Need Artificial Gravity?
44.plot: The Death Star is no moon, but it's close to the size of one, so does this mean it needs its own gravity? Is it even possible? Kyle stays on target on this week's Because Science.

45.title: How Do Cyclops' Eyes Work?
45.plot: Did you know that when Cyclops fires his optic blasts, portals to another dimension are opened inside his eyes? Kyle Hill breaks it down and explains how it all works on Because Science.

46.title: Could Wolverine's Claws Cut Superman?
46.plot: Wolverine's Adamantium additions are sharp, there's no question about that. But how sharp are they? Kyle Hill breaks down the science and we find out if Wolverine's claws can cut Superman.

47.title: How Loud is Hulk's Thunderclap?
47.plot: Pop culture concepts from the sci-fi (and sometimes fantasy!) worlds of video games, movies and TV are put under the microscope by Nerdist Science Editor Kyle Hill, who uses real-life math and science to explain, calculate or debunk them.

48.title: Why Star Wars' Tatooine Sunset Is Even Cooler with Science!
48.plot: Luke Skywalker's iconic Tatooine sunset scene is the stuff of film legend, but could it be even cooler? Kyle explains how on this week's Because Science.

49.title: How Lightsaber Color Tells Us What They're Really Made of!
49.plot: Lightsabers aren't made of light, nor are they saber shaped. And what's the deal with the different colors? Kyle Hill explains it all, in Because Science.

50.title: Why Chewbacca's Bowcaster Is Stronger Than Any Blaster!
50.plot: Han Solo became quite the fan of Chewie's bow-caster in Star Wars The Force Awakens and he had good reason because it's more powerful than any good old blaster. Kyle explains on this week's Because Science.

51.title: What Is Groot Made of?
51.plot: Guardians of the Galaxy's Groot looks like a tree, grows like a tree, sounds - like a tree, and is a tree. What is he made of? Kyle Hill gets to the root of the question on Because Science.

52.title: How Does Thor Summon Lightning?
52.plot: Thor has a heavy hammer and is the God of Thunder. Kyle Hill has explained most things about Thor, but how does he summon lightning? Watch and learn, on Because Science.

1.title: Why Godzilla's Atomic Breath Is Worse Than You Think!
1.plot: We go back to the theme of the very first Because Science and look at another part of Godzilla's biology, his atomic breath. It's not just fire or heat, it's much worse. Kyle spews some atomic information on this week's Because Science.

2.title: Can Magneto End The World?
2.plot: Magneto is one of the most powerful mutants to ever live, yet could be even more powerful than he even realizes. Kyle Hill breaks down seven powers that you didn't know Magneto has.

3.title: What Happens If An Infinity Stone Shatters?
3.plot: The Infinity Stones contain an unimaginable amount of power, in their own unique ways. But, what would happen if one shattered? Kyle Hill breaks it down, on Because Science.

4.title: How Do The Powerpuff Girls' Hands Work?
4.plot: The Powerpuff Girls don't actually have fingers, therefore they can't pick up anything - or can they? Kyle Hill breaks it down.

5.title: What Makes Overwatch's Widowmaker Tick?
5.plot: Widowmaker, the ever-so-annoying sniper in Overwatch, has blue skin, an insanely slow heart rate, and probably a bad case of scoliosis. What's the deal? Kyle Hill breaks down the science.

6.title: Could the MST3K Logo Fit On The Moon?
6.plot: Kyle Hill has always wondered something about the famous MST3K intro; could you actually fit the logo on the moon? He breaks down the science and teaches us, in Because Science.

7.title: Who's Faster: The Flash or Nightcrawler?
7.plot: The Flash is widely considered to be the fastest superhero, even being able to stop time. However, Nightcrawler has a loophole that mathematically makes him super fast as well. Is it fast enough? Kyle Hill breaks it down.

8.title: Can Kirby Inhale a Human?
8.plot: Kirby sucks, but we already knew that. Kirby can inhale lots of things - but is a human one of those things? Kyle Hill breaks down the science and answers the question: can Kirby inhale a human?

9.title: Are X-23's Claws Stronger Than Wolverine's?
9.plot: X-23 is a victim of the revived Weapon X program that gave Wolverine his claws. After 22 attempts to clone him, Laura Kinney was created. Kyle Hill breaks down the science of why her claws are stronger than Wolverine's.

10.title: The Power Behind Anime Nosebleeds
10.plot: You see it all the time in anime. A character gets an extreme nosebleed, some even being rocketed upwards due to it. Can a nosebleed actually be that powerful? Kyle Hill breaks it down.

11.title: What Would Happen if You Could Control Dark Matter?
11.plot: At the cosmic scale, dark matter can change the way that galaxies spin, and how light bends. If you could control dark matter, you might even become a biotic warrior. Kyle Hill breaks down the science.

12.title: Is Rita Repulsa's Staff More Destructive Than Her Monsters?
12.plot: The Power Rangers have faced many of Rita Repulsa's ginormous monsters, but could her staff be the real threat? Kyle makes the science grow on this week's Because Science.

13.title: Transferring Your Consciousness Into A Shell
13.plot: The anime film Ghost in the Shell featured technology powered consciousness transfer, but what would actually transfer to a shell? Kyle Hill breaks it down, on Because Science.

14.title: How Does Mass Effect's Omni-Tool Work?
14.plot: Every great science fiction series has great weapons. Mass Effect has the Omni-Tool, a tool that can also become a sword. How does the technology work? Kyle Hill breaks it down.

15.title: Can A Lightsaber Cut Through Adamantium?
15.plot: Star Wars has the lightsaber. Logan has his adamantium claws. But what if they crossed over and clashed? Can a lightsaber cut through adamantium? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

16.title: How Does Saitama One Punch The Rain?
16.plot: During One Punch Man, our hero ends up taking on The Sea King. during his fight, he punches - the rain. How exactly does that happen? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

17.title: Is Attack on Titan's 3D Maneuver Gear Deadly for Humans Too?
17.plot: Season 2 of Attack on Titan is out and Kyle Hill wants to know: Could 3D maneuver gear be deadly for its user as well as the Titan? Find out now on Because Science.

18.title: How To Survive In Space WIthout Oxygen
18.plot: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 hits theaters this week, so we answer an important question from the first one, could Star-Lord really survive in space without any protection? Kyle has the good, the bad, and a little bit of both on this week's Because Science.

19.title: What Would A Real Space Battle Look Like?
19.plot: Sci-fi space battles are really loud. Scientific space battles - not so much. Unfortunately, accurately portrayed space battles are less interesting, but what would they actually look like? Kyle Hill breaks it down.

20.title: Xenomorph Biology Explained!
20.plot: The Alien franchise has shown us many forms of aliens from facehuggers to xenomorphs, but how does it all work? Kyle bursts through with an explanation in this week's Because Science.

21.title: What Does Real Hyperspace Look Like?
21.plot: Star Wars often shows us their idea of what hyperspace would look like, but that begs the question: how would real hyperspace work? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

22.title: Does Wonder Woman Have the Sharpest Sword in the Universe?
22.plot: Wonder Woman is known for her skills in combat, but should she also be known for having the sharpest sword as well? Kyle breaks down her cutting edge weaponry on this week's Because Science.

23.title: How Powerful Is Yondu's Arrow?
23.plot: Yondu's arrow is one of the awesome things in Guardians of the Galaxy, but could it be explained by another magical character? Kyle has the spoonful of sugar to help explain on this week's Because Science.

24.title: Could A Portal Gun End All Life On Earth?
24.plot: Having a Portal gun (from the Portal video game series) would be a lot of fun, but could also be dangerous. How dangerous? Could it be so dangerous that it ends all life on Earth? Kyle Hill answers that question now, on Because Science.

25.title: The Definitive Xenomorph Lifecycle
25.plot: Alien Covenant added another dimension to the biology of xenomorphs, so how does it all fit now? Kyle puts it all together on this week's Because Science.

26.title: Could The Men In Black Neuralize You?
26.plot: 77% of Americans believe that aliens have visited Earth. But where's the evidence? Has our memory been wiped by MIB? Kyle Hill breaks down the science of the Neuralizer.

27.title: Why Does Spider-Man Cover His Body With A Suit?
27.plot: Spider-Man has a weird conundrum - he covers up all his cool spider characteristics with his suit. Kyle Hill breaks down the details on how science solves this issue.

28.title: How Many Dragons Would It Take To Melt The Wall?
28.plot: Even if you haven't watched Game of Thrones or read ASOIAF, you should still know it involves walls and dragons. But if the two collided (not literally), who would win? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

29.title: Can A Lightsaber Block Bullets?
29.plot: The lightsaber is a civilized weapon for a civilized age. But, what if that civilized age clashed with one that used guns? Kyle Hill answers the question "can a lightsaber block bullets?"

30.title: Are We Living In A Simulation?
30.plot: Is our reality really THE reality? Are we in a simulation, as we've seen depicted on Rick and Morty? What is real and what isn't? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

31.title: Is Double Jumping Physically Possible?
31.plot: If you've played video games, you know that double jumping is one of the most popular tropes. But could you double jump in real life? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

32.title: How Long Does A Spirit Bomb Take To Charge?
32.plot: Dragon Ball Z is a show of extremes, where attacks can destroy entire planets - like a spirit bomb. But how long does the spirit bomb take to charge?

33.title: The Physics Behind Bruce Lee's One-Inch Punch
33.plot: In terms of sheer popularity, the most popular martial arts move might be Bruce Lee's one-inch punch. It looks impossible, but is it? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

34.title: Can The Flash Take A Hands-Free Selfie?
34.plot: If you could run as fast as The Flash, you could do almost anything. But would you be fast enough to take a truly hands-free selfie? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

35.title: Street Fighter's Sonic Boom Actually Makes Sense!
35.plot: We're sure that you've heard of a sonic boom before and may even know the physics behind it. But do you know why Street Fighter's sonic boom makes sense? Kyle Hill breaks it down.

36.title: How Fast Do Tails' Tails Gotta Go?
36.plot: People sometimes forget that Sonic has an equally iconic side-kick: Tails. He's gotta go fast too, but how fast do his tails need to go in order to fly? Kyle Hill answers on Because Science.

37.title: Would Sandy's Treedome Implode Under Bikini Bottom?
37.plot: Sandy Cheeks lives in a tree-dome under the sea, but the sea is heavy. Realistically, should Sandy's tree-dome implode? Kyle Hill breaks it down on Because Science.

38.title: How Dense is Legolas in Lord of the Rings?
38.plot: Elves have many magical qualities especially in Lord of the Rings, even walking on top of snow, so just how dense would Legolas have to be to do it? Kyle has the elvish science on this week's Because Science.

39.title: How Strong Is the Kraken?
39.plot: The Kraken is one of the most feared mythical beasts ever for its ability to pull entire ships down under the waves. But how strong would it have to be to do that? Kyle has the gripping details on this week's Because Science.

40.title: Could You Implant Memories Into a Blade Runner Replicant?
40.plot: If you wanted to create the perfect replicant like in Blade Runner, giving them human memories would be necessary, but is it possible? Kyle racks his brain on this week's Because Science.

41.title: How Do Star Trek's Deflector Shields Work?
41.plot: Star Trek gave us the now sci-fi space standard of deflector shields, but how do they work? Kyle makes it so on this week's Because Science.

42.title: Why Does Captain America's Shield Bounce?
42.plot: Captain America's iconic vibranium shield can deflect anything, but should it be able to ricochet off things? Kyle throws his mighty science on this week's Because Science.

43.title: Is Stranger Things' Eleven More Powerful Than a Jedi?
43.plot: Star Wars may have Jedi masters of the Force, but could Stranger Things have the real most powerful telekinetic in Eleven? Kyle does some power lifting on this week's Because Science.

44.title: Why Shattering Thor's Hammer Would Destroy the Earth!
44.plot: Thor Ragnarok shows us the destruction of Thor's iconic hammer Mjolnir, but should it have shown even more Earth shattering damage? Kyle ragnarocks your mind on this week's Because Science.

45.title: How Thor Summons His Hammer Explained!
45.plot: Thor's hammer, Mjolnir, is a product of Asgard where magic and science are one and the same, so how does he summon it? Kyle hammers out the details on this week's Because Science.

46.title: Why You Would Not Want Superman to Reverse Time!
46.plot: Superman has many powers, but one of his most iconic scenes features one of the craziest with his reversal of time. But could this power be far more deadly to everything? Kyle takes it for a spin on this week's Because Science.

47.title: The Secret of Wonder Woman's Bullet Blocking!
47.plot: Wonder Woman is known for many things, but one of her iconic abilities is blocking bullets, but is it take more than just being fast and strong? Kyle has the high caliber science on this week's Because Science.

48.title: How They Should Be Killing Zombies on The Walking Dead!
48.plot: The Walking Dead's usual weapon of choice is a blade, but are they using them correctly? Kyle takes a stab on this week's Because Science.

49.title: How Would You Build a Real X-Wing?
49.plot: Star Wars has had a huge influence on pop culture and eventually even real life technology. So what would it take to make a real life piece of Star Wars tech? Kyle gets building on this week's Because Science.

50.title: Why Death by Lightsaber Would Be Much Worse in Real Life!
50.plot: Star Wars has told us that the lightsaber is an elegant weapon, but is that really true? Kyle has the cutting edge facts on this week's Because Science.

51.title: Why Do Stormtroopers Even Wear Armor?
51.plot: Stormtroopers are not only known for being terrible shots, but also getting zero protection from their armor. So why do they even bother? Kyle has not another drill on this week's Because Science.

52.title: How Deadly Is the Joker's Magic Pencil Trick?
52.plot: Heath Ledger's Joker is iconic for many reasons, but one particularly memorable scene is his disappearing pencil trick. But how bad would this be in real life? Kyle has the serious details on this week's Because Science.

imdb.title: Because Science
plot: Join Nerdist's Kyle Hill each week as he discusses the secret science in your favorite fandoms and pop culture.
